The Related Discourses

1. Aggregates

10. Delighting in Form

Thus have I heard:1 One time, the Buddha stayed in the kingdom of Śrāvastī at Anāthapiṇḍada Park in Jeta Grove.

It was then that the Bhagavān addressed the monks, “When you delight in form, you delight in suffering. Delighting in suffering, you can’t liberate yourself from suffering. Thus, when you delight in sensation, perception, volition, and consciousness, you delight in suffering. Delighting in suffering, you can’t liberate yourself from suffering.

“Monks, when you don’t delight in form, you don’t delight in suffering. Not delighting in suffering, you can liberate yourself from suffering. Thus, when you don’t delight in sensation, perception, volition, and consciousness, you don’t delight in suffering. Not delighting in suffering, you can liberate yourself from suffering.”

The monks who heard what the Buddha had taught then rejoiced and handed it down.

  1. Summary
    Impermanent, painful, empty,
    And not self; rightly considered;
    Four ways of not knowing;
    And delighting in form.

Endnotes

  1. This sutra is parallel to SN 22.29 and SA 2.10.
Translator: Charles Patton
